recordings.loc: Severn (near  Waubaushene), Simcoe County, Ontario
recordings.rmk: First heard faintly responding to playback for a marsh monitoring project. After the station was completed I paddled towards the bird, still calling and got fairly close to make this recording. It stopped calling and perched very close to my canoe where I was a able to take some good photos.

recordings.loc: Estrada da Fazenda , Ubatuba, São Paulo
recordings.rmk:
Ave respondendo playback e estando a 2 metros do microfone, porém oculta no denso taboal.
Neste dia a ave foi registrada outras vezes com mais gravações e também com registro fotográfico.
Dia com sol e massa de ar quente intensa após alguns dias com chuva.
A ave parecia muito atraída com o uso do playback, possivelmente um macho procurando uma provável parceira ou defendendo seu território de um falso invasor

recordings.loc: Severn (near  Coldwater), Simcoe County, Ontario
recordings.file-name: XC666865-LEBI calls 21:08:07 Lawson Line Osprey platform.mp3
recordings.rmk: Heard from known spot in extensive cattail marsh. Frequently seen flying into this location and suspect a nest site. The monotonous 3 note call I suspect may be a juvenile with adult responding with typical "rack,rack,rack" call. Other vocalizations I'm not certain of as there are Common Gallinule,Sora, and Virginia Rail families in the vicinity. Used high pass filter.

recordings.loc: Estrada da Fazenda , Ubatuba, São Paulo
recordings.rmk:
Ave oculta na vegetação de Taboas (Typha spp.) sendo impossível qualquer observação visual do indivíduo.
Dia de muito sol e calor na primavera de 2018.
É possível ouvir outro indivíduo da mesma espécie ao fundo.
Ave respondendo ativamente ao playback. Deixei o gravador ligado até a ave terminar a sequência do canto.
Gravação com uma serra elétrica ao fundo, pois próximo ao brejo há algumas casas.

recordings.loc: Ford River Township (near  Escanaba), Delta County, Michigan
recordings.rmk: When I had moved quietly into a new area of the marsh, and spoke softly into the microphone to say where I was, I startled an American Bittern that flew silently up and away farther into the marsh. Almost immediately a Least Bittern that was farther from me hidden in the cattails called and simultaneously flew in the same direction that the American Bittern had flown to. As it flew, it called two more times. By the third screech call, I had the parabola focused on it, so that screech is the clearest. I was unable to see the colors, so unable to sex that bird. However, a few minutes later, a male Least Bittern (with black dorsal surface and primaries) flew into cattails near me, and I photographed it (Photo is on Fickr.).  It was overcast and cool, about 50 degrees, and a thunderstorm was predicted, which didn't materialize.

recordings.loc: Santee, San Diego County, California
recordings.rmk: I did not hear the sound right away due to the high vocal activity from the other birds and sound pollution from the plane and other patrons at the park.  However, I picked out something out of place in the first patch of reeds at the southwest end of Lake #6.  My first thought was Pied-billed Grebes- which I had seen at previous lakes, but not at this one.  Additionally, the Pied-billed Grebes were calling throughout the day, so I got a good refresher as to what they are supposed to sound like.  Since this sound was non-variable, low in pitch, and only used four notes that did not change in volume or pitch, my second guess was Least Bittern since they are known to make "coo" sounds four to five times.  However, since I could not see nor call out the bird, and the sound was also not very clear or loud, I did not publish the sound right away since I was not certain.  Subsequent analysis by ornithology professor Dr. Kevin Burns of San Diego State University, and avid birdwatcher Matt Sadowski convinced me this was the bird I suspected.  The calls can be hear at approximately 0:02, 0:09, 0:16, and 0:28.

recordings.rmk: Hembra con plumaje reproductivo en Área Natural Protegida Laguna El Jocotal. Grabación de video con cannon power shot SX50 HS. Se utilizo el programa Audacity 2.0.4 no se utilizo ningún efecto, tiempo de la grabación  1.10 minutos con intervenciones a los 5", 20", 35", 40" y 1.10". Finalmente se convirtió  a mp3. Tipo de vegetación Sagittaria sp, Phragmites sp y vegetación flotante

recordings.rmk: Calling from Red Mangrove forest.   Its mate was feeding close by in the mangrove proproots.

recordings.loc: Imperial National Wildlife Refuge, Yuma County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: I was alerted to this birds presence when it made the LEBIs typical kek-kek-kek call and moved my kayak to the origin of the sound at the edge of some dense marsh grass.  I could hear the bird moving around so I knew it was in there and then it started making this vocalization when I was about 15 ft away.  I had never heard a LEBI do this before so I thought there might also be a CLRA in there.  I played the similar CLRA call and this bird responded immediately, making me think there was indeed a CLRA nearby.  But a moment later the bittern emerged and continued to make this vocalization as I watched it and got a video of it.

recordings.loc: Waterford, Lafayette County, Mississippi
recordings.rmk: It was really windy out today, so capturing quality audio was difficult. What's more, the LEBI song is pretty quiet and easy to overlook, which compounds the difficulty of recording it in adverse conditions. I never saw it, but it was concealed in aquatic vegetation near the shore.

recordings.loc: Medfield, Norfolk County, Massachusetts
recordings.rmk: Band pass filter (250 - 1500 Hz) and amplified. Lots of background noise.

recordings.loc: Arizona (near  San Carlos), Gila County, Arizona
recordings.rmk: I was kayaking a narrow stream which empties into a small man made lake.  There were cattail reeds on each side of the channel.  I could hear the low gutteral calls from the LEBI but never saw the birds until one flushed.  Some of the recording was edited to remove some loud sounds made accidentally.  The calls are not very loud and are low tonal.  Many background species also captured in recording.

recordings.loc: Estrada da Fazenda , Ubatuba, São Paulo
recordings.rmk:
Ave vocalizando de dentro do brejo , numa área de restinga úmida e pantanosa , com uma encosta ao fundo e um rio à frente .
No trabalho de tentar fazer o registro fotográfico da espécie , foram 7 visitas ao mesmo local , porém sem sucesso em nenhuma delas .
E
Não haviam outros registros desta espécie no município , portanto este é o primeiro .
Em dias de sol (como na data da gravação) a ave se mostrou mais ativa vocalmente , se aproximando da fonte do som , porém sem se mostrar .

recordings.loc: Needles, San Bernardino County, California
recordings.rmk: I was probably 20 ft from the birds in a shallow area of open water amidst a dense cattail marsh in the Colorado River.  Recording is unmodified and temps were about 90F and sunny.

recordings.loc: Richmond, Berkshire County, Massachusetts
recordings.rmk: After extensive playback, and while hearing other quiet sounds probably from a single Least Bittern, we were able to record this short series of calls.  Spectrally (and by sound to the ear) this bird sounds very similar to Least Bitterns giving the standard 'reek reeek' call that is usually given in a series more quickly than this.  Recording heavily edited to remove frequencies below 1000 khz and above 6500, and amplified by a factor of 2 in the remaining frequencies.  Extensive and large marsh system here, containing Sora and Pied-billed Grebe as well as dozens of Virginia Rails.

recordings.loc: Rioja, San Martin
recordings.rmk: This was natural song (very faint) of an unseen bird in tall marsh grass. A first record for San Martin, and perhaps the first away from the Peruvian coast or lowland Peruvian Amazonia?

recordings.loc: Peterborough, Peterborough County, Ontario
recordings.rmk: Trying to identify low(and barely audible) coo-coo-coo-coo sound on this recording. Heard at 1 sec and 14 sec (maybe also at 8 sec...seems to show up on sonogram but it is not audible to me). I was trying to record an American Bittern that was singing and noticed this sound that was also coming from the marsh. I am guessing this is an alternate call of American Bittern but it does bring to mind Least Bittern. Habitat is an extensive marsh where American Bittern has just arrived from the south. Not much else to be heard in recording other than a couple of types of frogs and Red-winged Blackbird. Haven't altered/filtered recording...not sure if it helps or hurts to filter the recording.
